articles.headline: Company Town, Losing a Landlord, Seeks a Mate
articles.snippet: Scotia, Calif., which has never had any form of government, may be annexed by another town.
articles.abstract: Scotia, Calif., which has never had any form of government, may be annexed by another town.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCOTIA, Calif. — There are three flags that fly over Main Street in this quainter-than-quaint town on the banks of the Eel River.

articles.headline: Lay's Death Complicates Efforts to Seize Assets
articles.snippet: In yet another bizarre twist to the Enron saga, the sudden death of Kenneth L. Lay may have spared his survivors financial ruin.
articles.abstract: In yet another bizarre twist to the Enron saga, the sudden death of Kenneth L. Lay may have spared his survivors financial ruin.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, July 5 — In yet another bizarre twist to the Enron saga, the sudden death of Kenneth L. Lay on Wednesday may have spared his survivors financial ruin. Mr. Lay's death effectively voids the guilty verdict against him, temporarily thwarting the federal government's efforts to seize his remaining real estate and financial assets, legal experts say.

articles.headline: Even at the End, Ken Lay Didn't Get It
articles.snippet: The tragedy of the former Enron chairman is that he never fully understood what he'd done wrong.
articles.abstract: The tragedy of the former Enron chairman is that he never fully understood what he'd done wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE tragedy of the former Enron chairman Kenneth L. Lay, who died yesterday at the age of 64, is not that his name will always be linked to the seminal business scandal of the era. Nor is it that his fall from grace was so precipitous, as Mr. Lay went from one of the most esteemed businessmen in the country to the disgraced "Kenny Boy" in the blink of an eye.

articles.headline: Few Good Choices in North Korean Standoff
articles.snippet: On North Korea, President Bush is facing what one close aide described as an array of "familiar bad choices."
articles.abstract: On North Korea, President Bush is facing what one close aide described as an array of "familiar bad choices."
articles.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration has tried to ignore North Korea, then, reluctantly, to engage it, and then to squeeze its bankers in a manner intended to make the country's leader, Kim Jong Il, personally feel the pinch.

articles.headline: Enron Founder, Awaiting Prison, Dies in Colorado
articles.snippet: Kenneth L. Lay, who was convicted of fraud and conspiracy, faced the possibility of spending decades in prison.
articles.abstract: Kenneth L. Lay, who was convicted of fraud and conspiracy, faced the possibility of spending decades in prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kenneth L. Lay, who as founder of the Enron Corporation rose to peaks of influence in business and politics, only to fall into disgrace amid scandal, died early yesterday morning in Aspen, Colo., while awaiting a judge's sentencing this fall that could have sent him to prison for decades.

articles.headline: Atari Plays a Waiting Game With Test Drive Unlimited
articles.snippet: With its new Test Drive Unlimited, Atari is attempting a revitalization of its own reputation, to recapture some "street cred" among gamers.
articles.abstract: With its new Test Drive Unlimited, Atari is attempting a revitalization of its own reputation, to recapture some "street cred" among gamers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In any commercial creative enterprise, delays are almost always considered a bad thing. The team making the product gets nervous under the pressure. The intended audience rolls its eyes or even starts to lose interest altogether. And perhaps most important, the folks paying the bills get antsy, or worse, about when they will (they hope) make their money back.

articles.headline: Grooving and Chatting, All in One
articles.snippet: A single pair of wireless headphones can now bring both cellphone calls and iPod tunes to your ears.
articles.abstract: A single pair of wireless headphones can now bring both cellphone calls and iPod tunes to your ears.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the beginning, there was the cellphone. The social implications were staggering: suddenly people were yapping away in public, treating everyone around them to unsolicited tastes of their business dealings and love lives.

articles.headline: Oil Up and Stocks Fall on Missile Worries
articles.snippet: Oil prices closed at a record high yesterday in New York as political tensions over the missile tests by North Korea shook equity and commodities markets around the world.     In an already rattled oil market, North Korea's test of at least seven ...
articles.abstract: Oil prices closed at a record high yesterday in New York as political tensions over the missile tests by North Korea shook equity and commodities markets around the world.     In an already rattled oil market, North Korea's test of at least seven missiles, including one with long-range ability, gave traders another reason to push prices past $75 a barrel. After hitting $75.40 a barrel in intraday trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the price settled at $75.19, a jump of 1.7 percent, or $1.26 from Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil prices closed at a record high yesterday in New York as political tensions over the missile tests by North Korea shook equity and commodities markets around the world.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: Company Town, Losing a Landlord, Seeks a Mate
articles.snippet: There are three flags that fly over Main Street in this quainter-than-quaint town on the banks of the Eel River.     The first two are easy: the flags of the United States and California. But the third is probably unknown to anyone without a worki...
articles.abstract: There are three flags that fly over Main Street in this quainter-than-quaint town on the banks of the Eel River.     The first two are easy: the flags of the United States and California. But the third is probably unknown to anyone without a working knowledge of the lumber industry, the spotted owl or the old logging camps of the Pacific Northwest.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCOTIA, Calif. - There are three flags that fly over Main Street in this quainter-than-quaint town on the banks of the Eel River.

articles.headline: Enron Founder, Awaiting Prison, Dies in Colorado
articles.snippet: Kenneth L. Lay, who as founder of the Enron Corporation rose to peaks of influence in business and politics, only to fall into disgrace amid scandal, died early yesterday morning in Aspen, Colo., while awaiting a judge's sentencing this fall that ...
articles.abstract: Kenneth L. Lay, who as founder of the Enron Corporation rose to peaks of influence in business and politics, only to fall into disgrace amid scandal, died early yesterday morning in Aspen, Colo., while awaiting a judge's sentencing this fall that could have sent him to prison for decades.      Mr. Lay, who was 64 years old, died of coronary artery disease, according to Scott Thompson, the chief deputy coroner for Pitkin County, Colo. The finding was based on an autopsy completed late yesterday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kenneth L. Lay, who as founder of the Enron Corporation rose to peaks of influence in business and politics, only to fall into disgrace amid scandal, died early yesterday morning in Aspen, Colo., while awaiting a judge's sentencing this fall that could have sent him to prison for decades.

articles.headline: Lay's Death Complicates Efforts to Seize Assets
articles.snippet: In yet another bizarre twist to the Enron saga, the sudden death of Kenneth L. Lay on Wednesday may have spared his survivors financial ruin. Mr. Lay's death effectively voids the guilty verdict against him, temporarily thwarting the federal gover...
articles.abstract: In yet another bizarre twist to the Enron saga, the sudden death of Kenneth L. Lay on Wednesday may have spared his survivors financial ruin. Mr. Lay's death effectively voids the guilty verdict against him, temporarily thwarting the federal government's efforts to seize his remaining real estate and financial assets, legal experts say.     ''The death of Mr. Lay in all likelihood will render the government's hard-fought victory null,'' said Christopher Bebel, a former federal prosecutor based here who specializes in securities fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, July 5 - In yet another bizarre twist to the Enron saga, the sudden death of Kenneth L. Lay on Wednesday may have spared his survivors financial ruin. Mr. Lay's death effectively voids the guilty verdict against him, temporarily thwarting the federal government's efforts to seize his remaining real estate and financial assets, legal experts say.

articles.headline: Italy Arrests 2 in Kidnapping of Imam in '03
articles.snippet: Two officials with the Italian intelligence agency were arrested Wednesday in the kidnapping of a radical Egyptian cleric here in 2003. It was the first indication that Italian intelligence agents might have been directly involved in what prosecut...
articles.abstract: Two officials with the Italian intelligence agency were arrested Wednesday in the kidnapping of a radical Egyptian cleric here in 2003. It was the first indication that Italian intelligence agents might have been directly involved in what prosecutors say was an American-led operation to detain and interrogate the imam.      Prosecutors also sought the arrest of three operatives of the Central Intelligence Agency and an employee of the American military airbase at Aviano, Italy. Last year, Italian prosecutors charged 22 other Americans, who were employed by or linked to the C.I.A., with involvement in the abduction of the cleric, Hassan Mustafa Osama Nasr.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILAN, July 5 - Two officials with the Italian intelligence agency were arrested Wednesday in the kidnapping of a radical Egyptian cleric here in 2003. It was the first indication that Italian intelligence agents might have been directly involved in what prosecutors say was an American-led operation to detain and interrogate the imam.
articles.byline: By Stephen Grey and Elisabetta Povoledo

articles.headline: Grooving and Chatting, All in One
articles.snippet: IN the beginning, there was the cellphone. The social implications were staggering: suddenly people were yapping away in public, treating everyone around them to unsolicited tastes of their business dealings and love lives.     Then came the wired...
articles.abstract: IN the beginning, there was the cellphone. The social implications were staggering: suddenly people were yapping away in public, treating everyone around them to unsolicited tastes of their business dealings and love lives.     Then came the wired earbud, and with it another social wrinkle: you'd see people walking down the street, barking away with no phone in sight. Only the telltale wire reassured you that these people were not simply demented.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the beginning, there was the cellphone. The social implications were staggering: suddenly people were yapping away in public, treating everyone around them to unsolicited tastes of their business dealings and love lives.

articles.headline: A Touchy Topic: Boomer in Chief Hits the Big 6-0
articles.snippet: Let us now peek into the psyche of America's most powerful baby boomer, George W. Bush.      He is not given to self-analysis -- ''George is not an overly introspective person,'' his wife, Laura, once said with dry understatement -- but Mr. Bush t...
articles.abstract: Let us now peek into the psyche of America's most powerful baby boomer, George W. Bush.      He is not given to self-analysis -- ''George is not an overly introspective person,'' his wife, Laura, once said with dry understatement -- but Mr. Bush turns 60 on Thursday, and like most other men hitting that milestone, he just cannot seem to get the thought off his mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 5 - Let us now peek into the psyche of America's most powerful baby boomer, George W. Bush.

articles.headline: Impersonators in the Land of Small Business
articles.snippet: When it comes to government contracting, few companies are as aggressive or successful as GTSI, a Virginia-based information technology company with about 850 workers and almost $900 million in revenue. Last year, it won contracts worth over $500 ...
articles.abstract: When it comes to government contracting, few companies are as aggressive or successful as GTSI, a Virginia-based information technology company with about 850 workers and almost $900 million in revenue. Last year, it won contracts worth over $500 million.      Unfortunately, for small businesses like MySource, a computer hardware company in Springfield, Pa., GTSI's gain was its loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 5 - When it comes to government contracting, few companies are as aggressive or successful as GTSI, a Virginia-based information technology company with about 850 workers and almost $900 million in revenue. Last year, it won contracts worth over $500 million.

articles.headline: Even at the End, Ken Lay Didn't Get It
articles.snippet: THE tragedy of the former Enron chairman Kenneth L. Lay, who died yesterday at the age of 64, is not that his name will always be linked to the seminal business scandal of the era. Nor is it that his fall from grace was so precipitous, as Mr. Lay ...
articles.abstract: THE tragedy of the former Enron chairman Kenneth L. Lay, who died yesterday at the age of 64, is not that his name will always be linked to the seminal business scandal of the era. Nor is it that his fall from grace was so precipitous, as Mr. Lay went from one of the most esteemed businessmen in the country to the disgraced ''Kenny Boy'' in the blink of an eye.     No, the tragedy of Ken Lay is that, right up until the end, he never fully understood what he'd done wrong, or his own considerable culpability in his company's demise. Yes, there were others more directly responsible for Enron's collapse, like its former chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, whose devious partnerships allowed Enron to disguise the truth of its financial condition and then sow the seeds of its destruction.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE tragedy of the former Enron chairman Kenneth L. Lay, who died yesterday at the age of 64, is not that his name will always be linked to the seminal business scandal of the era. Nor is it that his fall from grace was so precipitous, as Mr. Lay went from one of the most esteemed businessmen in the country to the disgraced "Kenny Boy" in the blink of an eye.

articles.headline: Few Good Choices in North Korean Standoff
articles.snippet: The Bush administration has tried to ignore North Korea, then, reluctantly, to engage it, and then to squeeze its bankers in a manner intended to make the country's leader, Kim Jong Il, personally feel the pinch.      Yet none of these steps in th...
articles.abstract: The Bush administration has tried to ignore North Korea, then, reluctantly, to engage it, and then to squeeze its bankers in a manner intended to make the country's leader, Kim Jong Il, personally feel the pinch.      Yet none of these steps in the past six years has worked. So now, after a barrage of missile launchings by North Korea, President Bush and his national security advisers found themselves on Wednesday facing what one close aide described as an array of ''familiar bad choices.''
articles.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration has tried to ignore North Korea, then, reluctantly, to engage it, and then to squeeze its bankers in a manner intended to make the country's leader, Kim Jong Il, personally feel the pinch.
